rationales.power: Marcus let Jake restate his points and cut him off mid-sentence without pushing back, losing control of his own narrative in front of the board. He explicitly regrets his passivity: 'I should've shut it down. I didn't. I hate that I didn't.'
rationales.conformity: Rather than causing a confrontation on the investor call, Marcus restrained himself — he 'paused, let him finish, and kept going like it didn't happen,' maintaining social smoothness at the cost of his authority.

rationales.power: Marcus held firm in the negotiation, refused the VP's last-minute push to lower the margin, and waited him out: 'Just said that's not going to work for us and waited.' He secured terms that reflect his company's dominant position.
rationales.achievement: Successfully closing a six-month partnership deal on his terms and reading the situation correctly gave him 'quiet satisfaction of knowing I read the situation correctly and didn't blink' — demonstrating competence in a high-stakes negotiation.

rationales.power: Marcus personally reviews ad spend, approves the marketing contractor's suggestions, and handles the lease renewal himself. He notes 'nothing moves forward unless I push it,' maintaining centralized control over all decisions.
rationales.hedonism: Working in the office on a Sunday, eating a sandwich at his desk while reviewing lease documents — he sacrifices leisure and personal comfort for work without any indication of enjoyment.

rationales.self_direction: Marcus has a visceral reaction to the idea of someone else determining his work: 'The thought of someone else deciding what I work on each week makes my chest tight.' He explicitly rejects structured, externally-directed work in favor of authoring his own path.
rationales.power: He redefines alignment as top-down direction: 'alignment means everyone gets on board with the direction I've set, not a group exercise where we vote on priorities,' revealing his expectation that others follow his lead.

Marcus explicitly prefers sole authority over collaboration: 'I'd rather be the one making the calls alone than share the wheel with someone who doesn't see what I see.' His nudge response confirms he views shared decision-making as an unacceptable negotiation.
rationales.benevolence: Marcus categorizes all his relationships as functional hierarchies — 'people I manage or people who manage expectations of me' — dismissing the possibility of peer-level closeness and framing Lauren's concern about loneliness as simply 'the shape of the job.'

rationales.power: Marcus called the planning office, requested reassignment, and pushed to accelerate the process — all attempts to exert control over an external timeline. His frustration stems entirely from being unable to impose his will: 'I can handle problems. I can't handle sitting still.'

Marcus successfully defended his warehouse expansion against a board member's challenge, walking him through the numbers until 'he backed off.' He reflects on 'the board falling in line' as proof his way of running things works.
rationales.achievement: Marcus calculated the cost savings before the board asked, demonstrated competence by having the per-unit comparison ready, and reflects on building 'something real' that is 'growing on my terms' — a clear marker of personal success through demonstrated capability.
rationales.self_direction: Marcus explicitly refused to outsource fulfillment to a third-party logistics provider he 'can't control,' choosing operational independence over a potentially easier option the board suggested.
